SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The CFM Sale Bill 1996 proposes to allow the Commonwealth to dispose of its interest in Commonwealth Funds Management and its subsidiaries to the private sector. CFM currently oversees such schemes as the public sector superannuation scheme and the Commonwealth superannuation scheme. CFM's monopoly over these two schemes lapsed on 30 June last year; hence, the trustees of the CSS and the PSS are free to place funds with Commonwealth Funds Management or with funds management organisations elsewhere. Since that time, the fund trustees have been free to use investment managers other than CFM, and have done so. However, it is reported that the Commonwealth record in funds management continues to lag behind best performance in the private sector.

SPEECH.PARA: Following the cabinet decision to gauge the extent of commercial interest in the sale of CFM, the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) announced the appointment of business and legal advisers to facilitate the sale. Both advisers, it was announced, would work in conjunction with the CFM sales team, the Department of Finance and CFM management on the scoping study, after which an appropriate method of sale would be decided. The government has stated that there has been strong interest in CFM as a result of the scoping study, and there has been some media speculation of a value of up to $130 million.

CFM has a subsidiary company, Total Risk Management, which provides strategic advice in the areas of asset allocation, portfolio restructuring, management selection and client reporting to the trustees of the CSS and the PSS. It is expected that Total Risk Management will also be sold when the CFM is sold. However, this remains to be determined by the commercial intentions of the winning bidder. Much of this bill focuses on the technicalities of privatisation, including exemptions from state or territory taxes on asset transfers and liabilities from CFM or its subsidiaries, and the cessation of certain rights, such as mobility rights under the Public Service Act 1922, when CFM is disposed of.

The CFM Sale Bill also raises interesting philosophical questions about privatisation. While this may be seen as a minor matter in comparison with a large national issue such as Telstra, these philosophical issues should be raised quite legitimately in debate. Unlike the approach of those opposite, Labor's approach to privatisation is not ideologically driven, in the narrow sense, by a need to own for ownership's sake or by the need to sell for the private sector's sake. We take a much more constructive view on ownership issues.

We support the active role of the public sector as an equalising and civilising force in our society. We examine the merits of public versus private ownership of utilities on a case‐by‐case basis. We are driven by the forces of good, rational policy making, not those of a blind obsession with ownership. Our desire to deliver good public policy gives Labor choice. We support the growth potential of the private sector and the power of market forces in some instances, but in other cases we believe the best outcome is delivered by the public sector.

BREAK.PARA: This leads me to what I have previously described as the `six key tests' governing privatisation; tests to which the ALP subscribes. Firstly, is the market already competitive? Secondly, can private capital play the role held by public capital? Thirdly, is it necessary for the taxpayer to contribute to the capitalisation of the public enterprise? Fourthly, are the market structure, its technology and public interest considerations such that public capital can be withdrawn? Fifthly, is the good essentially non‐universal, without significant benefits and spin‐offs for the community? Sixthly, is the market without substantial externalities?

I note that the member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) is writing down the six tests on privatisation that Labor applies; and well he might, because his side of politics does not have that level of rigour or assessment for deciding these issues. I believe that the Liberal Party is really in need of a philosophical approach to privatisation. It has what I would term a narrow ideological approach; that is to say, by its narrow definition, all public ownership of utilities is bad and all private ownership is good. Of course, in the broader sense of making good public policy, that is clearly inadequate. That narrow obsession with ownership as a test for privatisation is defying the national interest on a big public utility such as Telstra.

Let me just run through, for the benefit of the member for North Sydney and others in the Main Committee, a comparison on the six tests—the six criteria—that Labor uses in its comparison of Telstra, and our opposition to its privatisation, and CFM, the subject of this bill, and our support. The first test is: is the market already competitive? With regard to Telstra, of course, the answer is no. Telstra is the large public utility that dominates that market; some 80 to 90 per cent of the market comprises just one company. So there is not a fully competitive market. With regard to CFM, and whether the market is already competitive, I am led to believe that there are some 37 fund management organisations in Australia, so that is a large competitive market. There is no dominant player with some 80 to 90 per cent of market share.

The second test is: can private capital play the role held by public capital? In the case of Telstra, our assessment is no and, in the case of CFM, our answer is yes. I think that has been understood on both sides of the parliament. The third test is: is it necessary for the taxpayer to contribute to the capitalisation of the public enterprise? In the case of Telstra, the answer is no. Telstra returns a large surplus, which I believe both sides of politics are pleased to see returned to the community in the form of cross‐subsidies. That has been the past pattern of public ownership with Telstra. Private ownership, of course, raises the question of how sustainable those cross‐subsidies would be. In the case of CFM, and whether it is necessary for the taxpayer to contribute to the capitalisation of a public enterprise, I understand from the terms of this legislation that the answer is yes.

The fourth test is: is the market structure, its technology and public interest consideration such that public capital can be withdrawn? In the case of Telstra, the answer is no. The Labor Party believes, passionately, that the infrastructure for the so‐called information superhighway should remain in public hands. That is one of the core responsibilities of the public sector in the modern time. In the case of CFM, the market structure, technology and public interest do not necessarily have a consideration such that it needs to remain in public ownership.

The fifth test is: is the good essentially non‐universal, without significant benefits and spin‐offs for the community? In the case of Telstra, the answer is no. The good that we are talking about, the service of telecommunications and telephony in Australia, is of course universal, and it has significant benefits and spin‐offs across the community. In the case of CFM, the good is non‐universal. Again, we get a totally different answer out of the tests applied on privatisation by the Australian Labor Party.

By now, the member for North Sydney has probably jotted down all of the tests, one to five. The sixth test is: is the market without substantial externalities? In the case of Telstra, the answer is no. The substantial externality lies in industry policy, the great purchasing power of Telstra to support the growth and development of telecommunications in Australia. In the case of CFM, it is very hard to identify substantial externalities, particularly in a national sense.

So those are the six questions. In the case of CFM, the answer is one to six in the affirmative. In the case of Telstra, the answer is one to six in the negative. We get totally different circumstances and totally different outcomes once a proper, well thought out philosophical approach to privatisation is applied, instead of following a narrow ownership test and ownership alone. That is the substantial difference.

This debate and the criteria that I have outlined to the Main Committee highlight a stark contrast within this parliament: the Australian Labor Party has a pragmatic, well thought out philosophical approach to privatisation which we strongly believe matches up to the public interest; the Liberal Party is narrow, obsessive and ownership focused, without any broader approach.

I understand that the member for North Sydney, who is the next speaker, is pioneering new philosophies within the Liberal Party under the name of John Stuart Mill. I welcome that approach. You will learn much more from Mill than Lyons. We know that on the Labor side because he ratted on us. He had nothing to offer, he went over to the other side and offered even less. There is no doubt that, as the Liberal Party works out these philosophical questions in the 1990s—Mill versus Lyons—they will learn a lot more from Mill.

In that sense, I take inspiration from the member for North Sydney and I think he has something to offer his side of politics in sticking to the philosophy of John Stuart Mill. I think an objective observer—and in these matters I am trying so hard to be objective—would see that level of debate as a great advance for the Liberal Party on their past ideological struggles. How tawdry they were—Howard versus Peacock, wet versus dry, left versus right—throughout the 1980s. At least in the 1990s they have progressed to the point where it is John Stuart Mill versus Joe Lyons.

There is a need for all parliamentarians—party matters aside—to address these key philosophical questions and public interest considerations that arise out of privatisation. We need more parliamentarians to debate these matters. I recall some years ago one of my predecessors in Werriwa, Gough Whitlam—a great inspiration for me, as for many other Labor people—asking the question: `Comrade, where are all the lawyers?' He was talking about our side of politics. Looking at the Liberal Party benches as one considers the issue of a philosophical approach to privatisation—

TALK.START.PARA: —We've got plenty of them.

—The member for North Sydney points out they have got plenty of lawyers. That is right—you have too many lawyers. The question on the Liberal Party side is: where are all the economists? Where are all the economists who are making a contribution to policy and thinking as we grapple with some of the key economic issues, including privatisation, in the post‐industrial society? I think the member for North Sydney has some background and expertise in this area. He has made some quite enlightened speeches, consistent with John Stuart Mill, consistent with small `l' liberalism—which is a welcome trend on his side of the House. There is a gap to be filled and maybe he is the person on the Liberal Party side who will fill that gap. Maybe he is the economist.
—Don't give him the kiss of death!
—No, that's right!

—I am just trying to be hopeful. I suppose in opposition you look at these things and not only do you think about your own side but you also have time to think about the others. We think about them and we hope good things come out of the John Stuart Mill Society for the national interest. The most important thing—and it is directly relevant to the CFM sale—is that they flesh out a full philosophical, public interest approach to privatisation, not a narrow ideological obsession with ownership and ownership alone. So the hopes of the Liberal Party rest on the broad shoulders of the member for North Sydney, and to some extent—as long as they remain in government—the hopes of the nation. Maybe that is the kiss of death; maybe it can also be regarded as kind, generous words of encouragement.

BREAK.PARA: It should be noted that the government's approach to privatisation is nowhere near as reasoned as Labor's. During the Telstra debate, government members argued obsessively that the ALP is bound to support the sale of Telstra because we initiated the sale of the Commonwealth Bank and Qantas. The difference between those utilities and the case of Telstra is clear on each of the six criteria and tests that I have outlined for privatisation. I believe it is a credit to the Australian Labor Party that it has the maturity and capability for debate on these matters and that the outcomes at which we arrive are the product of policy making rigour and, above all, the best interests of our constituency.

Coalition members in this place and beyond would arrive at the same conclusions on Telstra if they were to apply a privatisation test that makes most sense. Above all, they would vote for the best interests of their constituencies, for the maintenance of cross‐subsidies that provide hundreds of millions of dollars per annum to their electorates. They would vote for public information technology which would make itself accessible to regional Australia. But, as we have seen in this place time and time again, the National Party, in particular, have conducted a clearance sale on their philosophy. They stand for very little, let alone a coherent position on the privatisation of public assets—and I am saddened to say that with you in the chair, Mr Deputy Speaker.

TALK.START.PARA: —The chair has no party, no matter who is occupying it.

—No. But in your other life, as a National Party member when you are not in the chair, I am saddened that it has come to this. By contrast, Labor's criteria for privatisation reflects our understanding of the differences between privatisation and competition; two very different economic concepts, both in their theory and their practice. Unlike those opposite, Labor is capable of distinguishing privatisation from competition because the two concepts are capable of producing vastly different outcomes.

BREAK.PARA: Labor applies the following principles to competition policies—they are our four fundamentals for the public sector—and, again, the member for North Sydney sharpens his pencil in expectation. First, adopting a sector‐by‐sector, case‐by‐case framework by which the different imperatives and outcomes of competition policy can be judged. Unlike the coalition, we are not locked into the dogma of competition at any cost. We believe passionately in the active role of the public sector as an equalising and liberating force in our society—something that even members of the John Stuart Mill Society could support.

Secondly, rejecting competition policy as an end in itself. It is critical in this policy area to separate means, the ideology of competition markets, from ends, enhanced competitiveness. In cases where the impact on competition is marginal, Labor opposes competition policies which have a net impact of withdrawing public resources, jobs and services from rural and regional economies. Labor is fundamentally committed to the role of the public sector in funding the cost of distance in Australia. As we talk about the role and size of the public sector, there could be no more relevant public discourse than to consider that in a big country like ours there is a genuine role for government in funding the cost of distance, the cost of funding services and utilities across a large continent; utilities being infrastructure, of course.

TALK.START.PARA: —Private tollways.

—You like tollways and you advised the member for Macarthur in your former capacity to that effect, but tollways and infrastructure have a great equity function, and the equity function is, first and foremost, not to levy the tolls on those who cannot afford to pay. That was the policy of the Greiner and Fahey governments. Freeways on Gore Hill in your electorate, but tollways and user‐pays on road facilities in my electorate. That is a stunning double standard that reverses concepts of equity. Why should the richest part of Sydney get a freeway and one of the poorer parts of Sydney get a tollway? So Labor has not only the philosophy but also the compassion that judges these issues with regard to equity. The equity consideration in a big country like ours is equality of opportunity and equality of access. To fund the cost of distance, it is not possible in a nation like ours to have services and facilities provided universally around the nation unless government is playing that role. That is one of the very strong arguments why Telstra should remain in public ownership.

BREAK.PARA: I continue, having disposed of the protests of the member for North Sydney on infrastructure matters. In cases where the impact on competitiveness is marginal, Labor opposes competition policies which have a net impact of withdrawing public resources, jobs and services from rural and regional economies. We do not believe there is a replacement effect whereby the private sector automatically takes over the functions and spending power of the public sector. With the corrosive impact of globalisation on social capital and civil society, there is in fact more work for the public sector to undertake as an expression of collective interest and collective action, not less.

The third principle is ensuring that competition policy does not result in de facto privatisation. It should not be a device by which the public sector is left to wither on the vine. That has so unhappily been the pattern of policy making in states like Victoria, where competition policy is used as an alibi for privatisation. It is used as a way of running down the size and capacity of the public sector and then, in the budget formulation, saying that there is no choice but to dispose of these assets for the sake of a short‐term bottom line benefit. Competition policy should be on a truly level playing field with public sector competitors given the same access to capital and markets as the private sector. Labor is in the business of fully resourcing the core functions of government.

Fourthly, and finally, ensuring the use of public benefit tests by the federal and state governments gives full weight to legitimate welfare equity, environmental and regional development issues, as initiated under the former Labor government.

Let me just wrap up my remarks by applying these tests on privatisation and competition policy to the principles underpinning this bill, the CFM Sale Bill. According to its recently tabled annual report on 30 June this year, CFM had $8.8 billion under management, including $1.8 billion managed by other fund managers under the TRM arrangements. In the last financial year, CFM obtained $379 million of new funds under its management. In 1995‐96 CFM made a profit of some $2.6 million and paid a dividend to the Commonwealth of $1.6 million. CFM is a profitable organisation and it is paying a dividend to the shareholder. That said, the opposition does not see a core need for the public sector to operate in the funds management advice area, and accordingly we will not be opposing this legislation. This decision is consistent with the trend in the last decade for the public sector to withdraw from operating businesses in financial markets, be they banks, insurance companies or funds management bodies. Again, those decisions of withdrawal, particularly in the case of the Commonwealth Bank, are consistent with the tests and criteria I outlined earlier to the Main Committee on privatisation.

As previously stated, CFM has not enjoyed a monopoly right to manage the funds of Commonwealth superannuation since July 1995. The introduction of competition works both ways, and this is a very important point for members to acknowledge. CFM not only manages funds for Commonwealth superannuation funds but is also free to compete for the business of other public and private sector funds. It has been reasonably successful in pursuing new clients outside its traditional market. By 1995‐96, the retail side of CFM's operations has grown to more than $300 million of funds under management. That, essentially, reflects a truly level playing field.

If we are to apply the principles of competitive neutrality, they need to be a two‐way street so that private sector organisations can compete against the public sector. We should not be shackling or in any way restricting the capacity of the public sector to, in turn, compete against the private sector, to defend its market share and even expand its market share if the private sector is not competitive.

That is a principle of competitive neutrality that the Howard government, quite shamefully, are watering down because they do not believe that competitive neutrality is a two‐way street. They see it as a one‐way street, all for the benefit of the private sector competing against the public sector. I urge this government, in their competitive neutrality statements, as I do tory governments in the states, to reassess the criteria and guarantee to the taxpayer, and the public, that competitive neutrality is a two‐way street.

Public sector employees should not be shackled in their capacity to compete against the private sector. Yet, if one examines the Kennett government policies on, say, pathology, one can see that they have been shackled. I have had questions on the Notice Paper about the government's policies on administrative services. The member for North Sydney should read and analyse them, and even take them to the John Stuart Mill Society and put up a debate about competitive neutrality.

TALK.START.PARA: —About risk capital.

—Risk capital, competition neutrality, privatisation. The member should take those issues forward, give them proper scrutiny and argue the very strong case that competitive neutrality should be a two‐way street, not a one‐way street. With a two‐way street, the public sector can compete vigorously with assets, with resourcing, and with capability, without any restrictions at law against the private sector, particularly in those instances where the private sector is anti‐competitive and engaging in restrictive practices against the public interest.

BREAK.PARA: As I have mentioned, CFM is a profitable organisation. We regard the decision and the bill as consistent with the trend in the last decade with regard to financial markets. The introduction of competition should work both ways and that is a key principle by which the Labor Party addresses these matters.

Despite an improvement in performance since the creation of CFM out of the former superannuation fund investment structure, the Commonwealth's record in funds management has generally lagged behind the best private sector performers. However, it should be noted that CFM is considered a very good performer in the area of fixed interest. Some of CFM's recent performance ratings provide an indication of the cost and effort which would involve the Commonwealth maintaining its stake in Commonwealth superannuation funds.

The latest Intech superannuation performance survey ranked CFM at number 32 out of 37 super funds in the 12 months to March 1996. CFM managed growth fund return currently rates seven per cent lower than the ANZ's ranking. Any attempt by the government to revitalise CFM would involve an injection of funds into the company. It is the view of CFM managing director—

TALK.START.PARA: —What's wrong with that?

—There is a problem with that. In the third test I put forward to the committee, the taxpayer should not, in cases such as this, be expected to fund the revitalisation of CFM if there is a better use within other markets for that scarce public resource, the scarce injection of risk capital. For the member for North Sydney to be singing the virtues of public sector risk capital I would have thought is contrary to all the rhetoric on his side of politics.

BREAK.PARA: The Labor Party believes there is a role for public sector risk capital but it has got to be carefully targeted to anti‐competitive markets where there is no alternative, where the public sector will not play a role in terms of risk capital. To whatever extent, say, Telstra takes a risk in the market that is not a risk that is being shared across the entire economy, then Telstra, as the dominant player, bears most of the responsibility for any market risk. There is a legitimate role for the public sector in that capacity. Any allocation of public resources bears some risk. It might not be capital risk, but there is always management risk in public sector allocations, on and off budget. So that needs to be understood.

As I understand it, the board of the CFM has been consulted on these matters and concurs with the proposal to privatise. At a time when vital social services are being savagely reduced by this government, the opposition is of the view that priority in public outlays should not include a capital injection to CFM. Accordingly, this legislation is not opposed.

I do flag, however, Labor's position relating to the sale of CFM and the administration of ComSuper. I believe the government is examining the possibility of rolling from CFM privatisation into privatisation of ComSuper administration. That is something which the opposition has severe reservations about. Such an action could be inconsistent with our criteria and tests for determining privatisation. Now is not the time and place to run ComSuper administration through those tests and criteria but I know that my colleague, the member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), who will be speaking on this bill, has strong views on the matter. He and the member for Canberra (Mr McMullan) are powerful advocates within the ACT on employment considerations relating to the administration of ComSuper and he is better placed than I to explain the detail and public interest considerations to the committee. I conclude at that point. I commend a philosophical approach to privatisation issues. I look forward to the comments of the member for North Sydney, but restate that the opposition as such will not be opposing the CFM sale legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hockey, Joe, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham), firstly for joining with the members of the opposition in supporting the CFM Sale Bill, but most importantly I thank him for bowling a few full tosses in the first 15 overs to give me the opportunity to hit them out of the oval. I will deal with some of the comments made by the member for Werriwa. Firstly, I will deal with the philosophical approach of the Australian Labor Party to privatisation.

SPEECH.PARA: The six criteria that he mentioned I will just go through very quickly. Firstly, is the market competitive? I do not remember us having a terribly competitive aviation market when the Australian Labor Party chose, when it was in government, to sell Qantas. In fact, it went to the Australian people saying, `Well, we're only going to sell a small part, given that there is not a terribly competitive market.' Indeed, it went ahead and sold the total shareholding of the Commonwealth government in Qantas and no‐one could argue for one second that there was a terribly competitive market in domestic aviation at the time. That is the first contradiction.

The second contradiction is private versus public capital; should we have public capital invested in GBEs—specifically in relation to Telstra—or should we be replacing it with private capital? If I remember correctly, one of the key arguments about the initial sale of Qantas was the fact that it did need capital. There were good reasons at the time perhaps and many people in the member for Werriwa's party argued that the ALP should retain all of the shareholding in Qantas. But no, they chose to go outside of the regular markets and, instead of debt financing, they chose to raise capital through a partial sale of Qantas. There is the second contradiction and I am only up to the second criterion.

The third criterion was whether the taxpayer should contribute to the overall capital of the enterprise. What the member for Werriwa was saying was that whenever one of these GBEs needs some capital, we should sell. That seems to contradict the second principle. But if an enterprise is in need of capital, either it is not being profitable—it is a diminishing asset and it is time to sell—or it needs capital and you are trying to bolster up the share value of the asset. There seem to be contradictions, again, in the ALP's policy on that point.
The fourth issue is in market structure. Is the market sufficiently competitive, and I think that is what the member for Werriwa was getting at—
Mr Latham interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it competitive that we should withdraw public funds from that part of the sector.
—No. That is not the point. The second and the fourth ones are wrong.
—Perhaps the member for Werriwa should provide me with a more detailed explanation of the four criteria.
—You check the Hansard .
—With great respect to the member for North Sydney, I would prefer he did not invite the member for Werriwa to participate in the debate at this stage.

—The fifth criterion is the community benefits of the sale. The ALP across Australia has failed to adopt a consistent policy in relation to this point. In New South Wales, for example, the ALP chose to say that there was a certain benefit in the sale of Axiom funds management, but there was no public benefit in the sale of the State Bank of New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a contradiction. It certainly contradicts what the member for Werriwa just said, because there was overwhelming public interest in the sale of state banks. I believe it is quite tragic that the Queensland government has chosen to invest in a state bank at a time when—

TALK.START.PARA: —Tragic!

—Yes, it is tragic at a time when it is important that state governments recognise the failures of the 1980s and so get out of the ownership of banks. Even in the dying days of the Cain government, they could not come to terms with the fact that governments are actually very bad owners of financial institutions. The sixth criterion I would have to summarise as the effect on the overall economy of—
—Externalities.

—Externalities of the sale of an asset. There is no doubt in my mind that the Australian economy will benefit from the partial sale of Telstra, but Telstra is not what we are dealing with in this case. The Liberal Party has a very clear philosophy on the selling of assets.
—What is it?

—The Liberal Party's criteria are not dissimilar to some of the more coherent criteria espoused by the member for Werriwa, but they are dissimilar as to the question of degree. The first question is: is there a public interest in owning the asset? In a world that is changing quite rapidly, certainly in terms of financial markets and most definitely in terms of communications, the markets are changing faster than the ownership criteria.

SPEECH.PARA: As such, we find that, for example, Telstra is a global player in the communications market, not necessarily just a domestic player. Therefore, if you assess the market that it is operating in as simply a domestic market, you are making a gross mistake about some of the effects of the sale on that market.

The second question is: is there a competitive market? We believe that where there is evidence of a competitive market the asset should be sold. In some areas that is not the case. It certainly varies from area to area. For example, in Victoria there is a competitive market in the area of electricity. In New South Wales, the electricity generators have been put into a competitive market.

Over time I would place a lottery ticket on the fact that the Carr government will be selling some generators. That is because they now have a competitive market for the supply of electricity and, with the development of the national grid, that will go even further.

The third question is: can the private sector do the job? The private sector has matured significantly since the days when Sir Robert Menzies chose to sell the Commonwealth's part stake in General Motors Holden. The market has developed because the Australian economy, even though it was born out of public sector enterprises, has developed as an internationally competitive economy, a significant part of which is based on the development and the contributions of the private sector.

BREAK.PARA: Therefore, in certain areas there is a very strong private sector level of activity. They are the three main criteria. Of course, one of the most significant criteria that the coalition government takes into account is what is in the best interests of the shareholder and what is in the best interests of the GBE that we are choosing to sell.

That brings me to Commonwealth Funds Management. As the Minister for Finance (Mr Fahey) said in the second reading speech, CFM provides investment services in the public and private sectors. Its major clients are the board of trustees of the Commonwealth superannuation scheme and the public sector superannuation scheme.

CFM is a wholesale funds manager for a number of other public and private sector funds. It is involved in retail funds management for individual investors via its superannuation and general investment products. Its sale reflects the fact that governments around the world are selling out of companies that are involved in financial services.

We have had, throughout Australia, a rapid change in relation to bank ownership, and that has been the catalyst for the domino effect of more recent times in the change of ownership of various financial institutions around the country. That has extended to insurance, such that GIO, SGIC, SIO and perhaps some of the other state‐owned organisations that deal in insurance are being sold—all except, of course, those of the Queensland government, which is choosing to invest. The state government in New South Wales—the Labor colleagues of the federal opposition—are in fact selling Axiom, which is the old state super fund, and it is to be sold within five years. However, in the case of Axiom, they are providing a five‐year fixed contract, I understand, which guarantees that the new purchasers will have access to the current level of funds under management for at least five years.

Why should the Commonwealth sell its stake in CFM? The first principle is that the private sector can do the job. There are $320 billion in managed funds in Australia, of which $245 billion is in superannuation. Contrary to the comments by the member for Werriwa, there are actually more than 37 firms managing superannuation. I believe there are at least 62. The most significant firms are some of the more established names that the Australian people are familiar with: AMP, Bankers Trust, Lend Lease, National Mutual and the Queensland Investment Corporation. There is a very strong degree of competition at this level, and Commonwealth Funds Management—in the table provided by the Australian Investment Managers Association 1996 annual report—came in at number 15 with $6,914.9 million under management, which represented 2.11 per cent of the overall market.

However, we have a diminishing asset. Why? Firstly, there was a legislative monopoly provided to CFM over CSS and PSS funds. However, that legislative monopoly ended on 30 June 1995. It is somewhat ironic that, before the 1993 federal election, the government at the time chose to renew the contract—perhaps with a belief that they might not be re‐elected and therefore might not have to deal with the problem. But we all have to deal with the problem, because CFM have certainly suffered because of the ending of the legislative monopoly.

Since that time, CSS and PSS have put $7 billion of their funds out to tender, and CFM has lost 27 per cent of that amount: around $1.89 billion. Most of the funds lost have been in active funds. Where the funds manager has active funds, the funds manager is trying to outperform the index. This is high margin business for a funds manager, and I understand that CFM has lost $1.3 billion in active funds management in 1995‐96. The tender was on the advice of Total Risk Management, which is a subsidiary of CFM, so there was no suggestion at all that Total Risk Management were providing advice other than that which is in the best interests of the trustees of the funds.

The focus on the loss of high margin business has not precluded CFM from being involved in passive funds management, which is the core of its business. But passive funds management, because it is all about index weighted investments, is not as profitable; and the cost has come to the fore only in the last 24 hours, when CFM announced that its net profit for the 1995‐96 financial year had fallen from $7.1 million to $2.7 million. And that is despite the fact that the net assets have actually increased to $21.928 million.

The second area where the asset is diminishing is because of the competitive market. As I mentioned earlier, there is a highly competitive market in funds management and, therefore, margins are significantly tighter. There is a greater volatility in overall markets, whether it be in interest rates or equities or perhaps even real estate, than there has been over the last 20 years. Even though there are obviously ways for funds managers to hedge that risk of volatility, it does come at some degree of cost. One of the costs is that funds managers are relying increasingly on top quality research. This is not to say that CFM does not have access to that top quality research, but what it does mean is that CFM needs to be able to pool its research abilities with other major players in order to provide an across‐the‐board service to its clients. Otherwise, there is an opportunity for CFM to focus on particular market areas, to become a niche player, and that provides a level of contradiction with its main source of funding, which is the funds of the Australian public servants. The bottom line is that the Commonwealth is not in the business of funds management, and I am very pleased that the opposition agrees with us on this; that it is not a core activity of the Commonwealth government.

I believe that, in this case, there is no doubt that staff will be the beneficiaries of the sale. Allan Moss, the chief executive of Macquarie Bank, was recently quoted as saying that the greatest asset of the bank walks out the door on a Friday afternoon, and it is quite true, particularly in relation to financial services, that the quality of the assets of a financial institution is essentially based on the quality of its staff. I believe that CFM do have very good quality staff. However, they have had a difficult time. Often vendors underestimate the effect on staff of a sale process. Whenever there is great uncertainty, such as the uncertainty created by the opposition and the Democrats in relation to the sale of Telstra, it does have a significant detrimental effect on staff morale, and it does have an effect on the attitude of staff to their determination to pursue a career within that organisation—perhaps not in relation to Telstra, where the government have already said there is going to be a public float, but certainly in relation to trade sales, where even the vendor does not know who the purchaser will be until contracts are signed—and staff do lose confidence in an organisation. However, according to the report of the chief executive of CFM, the staff have reacted very well to the ups and downs of the sale process.

They have also, of course, gone through a difficult time over recent years associated with the change in the nature of the business; that is, not just the make‐up and structure of CFM but also the fact that they have lost a significant amount of funds associated with active investments.

However, the staff will have broader career opportunities in the future under private ownership. Inevitably, in financial markets there is a certain risk associated with a job, but remuneration is very high because the workload is overwhelming, and I believe that, at the end of the day, the staff will be better remunerated under private ownership and they will certainly enjoy a more stable working environment.

This bill, under part 3, protects the current entitlements of staff and also provides a special protection for existing leave entitlements. The customers will also benefit. They will have access to a new organisation that will enjoy the efficiencies of a national network. Overheads will be cheaper, which allows CFM to provide a better margin on its costs.

The sale process is all‐important. It should be smooth and avoid troubles. And it is important that, on both sides of the House, we talk up the potential of the asset, which I think all members of this House would agree is significant in its potential new environment. This bill also provides flexibility. For example, in part 2, subsidiaries such as TRM can be transferred back to the Commonwealth. It may not be appropriate for TRM to be a part of the final sale, and I readily accept that.

At the end of the day, the most important point, of course, is what the shareholders get for the asset in terms of price. As Australian taxpayers, we have borne the risk of owning the asset over the years. It is most important that we maximise price, but balance it with some of the other issues that I have referred to. I wish the minister all the best for the sale and wish the staff of CFM a profitable and very productive future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) said that Labor supports the CFM Sale Bill 1996 and I, too, will support it. But I do have some reservations about the sale and I think it is worth expressing those as part of the debate. This is only a small issue, not a major issue, and I think it should be treated on quite practical grounds. It is not an intensely ideological issue at all. It seems to me that good policy is normally made in a context of commitment to goals, but also in a situation where one is pragmatic about means.

SPEECH.PARA: The goals that we should be committed to are ones about the security of people. That includes opportunities for employment and adequate income. It includes maximum freedom—one wants no more government intervention than is necessary to achieve agreed goals and to achieve the common good. There is a balance, of course: how to balance the interests of the individual and the interests of the whole community. We also have to have a commitment to equity because if our society becomes very unequal then it becomes divided, and that causes division, tension and possibly serious breakdown and conflict. Everyone also wants an opportunity for a lively life, an attractive life, where there is plenty of opportunity for full human, spiritual and cultural expression.

In the context of those goals, is it possible to draw out any principles or issues that might relate to this very small and very specific issue? The honourable member for Werriwa attempted to do so and the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) also followed up with some of those issues. On several of the issues that they discussed, I think it would be quite possible to take an alternative view. If, for example, you look at the public interest, the central question is: what is in the best interests of the contributors in the public sector? It could be that their interests will be best served by having this organisation privately owned. It is almost entirely a private industry. But I will come, in a minute, to some ways in which it may be beneficial to keep this small part of that industry in the public sector.

The same sort of point could be made in relation to contributors generally, and I will come to that now because the second issue that both previous speakers raised was about market structure. They said that this is a competitive market structure, but I am honestly not convinced about that. It is true that there are many organisations involved in the industry, but it is also absolutely true that there are conventions about the fees that the managers charge which enable them to have a very comfortable, relatively high income situation.

In other words, I am not convinced that this industry is really and intensely competitive. Even though there are many companies involved, they all operate at very similar margins. They charge quite surprisingly high fees. Normally, I understand, they charge somewhere between 0.3 per cent and 0.7 per cent of the value of the capital asset each year. That gives them very high incomes in a situation where the only risk for them is the risk of losing the funds that they manage. It is not their money that they are managing; it is someone else's money.

The risk for them is that they may lose their market share. Of course, they have to struggle to keep market share; they have to demonstrate that they are operating professionally but, as in other professions, such as the medical and legal professions, there are professional norms about fees which are very high and which deprive contributors of a significant proportion of the income that their funds receive every year, and that does not suggest that this is a really competitive situation. In that kind of structure, therefore, a reasonable case can be made, I think, for keeping a small part of it in public ownership so as to have both greater intensity of competition and possibly a window into what is happening in the industry.

When I wanted to find out about what was happening in this industry five years ago, I went to a superannuation fund investment trust, the predecessor of the Commonwealth Funds Management. They were quite happy to tell me what they were doing and what others were doing. They were not breaking any commercial‐in‐confidence information but, because they were in the public sector, they were more accessible than a private company would have been. That sort of advice would also continue to be available to government if government kept this in public ownership. So, I think that a case can be made in terms of even market structure for keeping this in public ownership. It is not a very strong point. It is an on‐balance point, but I put it forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps cross the floor?

—You are the ones who are selling it. I have already really touched on the issue of externalities. I think that the externality in this case is the possibility of keeping information and advice to government more readily available than it would be if it were sold off.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me return for a minute to the issue of the fees. I hope that at some point this parliament will do an inquiry into this industry. It is an enormously important industry and, in a sense, our whole economic future depends on it because of the level of funds that it has got under its control. It is now well established, and I think that it would be entirely appropriate for there to be a parliamentary inquiry at some point.

TALK.START.PARA: —Into technology, as well.

—Into many aspects of it, not just the issue of fees, but the way that the relationship between trustees and management organisations operate, and the basis on which decisions are made. There are many issues there that warrant study. Now would be a suitable time to do it because the industry is off and running well and truly. If it had been kept in public ownership, there would, of course, be no risk to contributors at all because the trustees still have the opportunity for moving all the funds to somebody else if they so choose. It is a bit of a red herring which one or two speakers have raised in other places.

BREAK.PARA: As to the issue of profitability, the facts as outlined by the honourable member for Werriwa were absolutely true. In recent times, particularly during the last year or two, Commonwealth Funds Management has been at the lower end of rates of return amongst investment fund managers because of the balance of its portfolio. It invested fairly heavily in property, and property has not done well in recent years. Others have other structures and they have done better when the Stock Exchange is up. As property recovers, as it certainly will, the funds under management by Commonwealth Funds Management will do better, as well. So, I do not think that that is a simple issue.

Of course, the important point in relation to profitability is: what is the level of return at the time contributors retire? It is impossible to know that. We have the proxy of estimating returns in the short term—three months, a year, three years, five years—and that is the best that we can do. But it is only a proxy. The ultimate test needs to be: how effectively were the funds managed at the time the contributor retired?

If it had been kept in public ownership, there would have been no cost to the Commonwealth at all. I think the honourable member for Werriwa, by the way, was wrong about the need for a capital injection. I do not think there was any requirement for a capital injection at all. It is a tiny organisation, Commonwealth Funds Management, simply managing funds. It does not require capital itself. There is no risk capital involved by the Commonwealth at all.

Another point in relation to the issue of contributors is that, when an organisation has been privatised, management have always increased their own salaries. In some of the privatised industries in Britain, the management executive salaries have doubled or trebled and it has been quite disgraceful to see what has happened in Britain. I am not saying that that would automatically happen here but I bet that if this is sold, then the salaries will rise.

Finally, on the issue of what might happen after the sale, there has been a suggestion that Lend Lease is one of the bidders for purchase of Commonwealth Funds Management and that it has offered two seats to the CPSU. That would be very valuable if it happened because that would ensure that contributors were directly represented in the control of the privatised Commonwealth Funds Management. I would strongly support that if it happened but there is no—

TALK.START.PARA: —I have one more point to make and that is in relation to the possible privatisation of the management of the Commonwealth superannuation funds. The sale of Commonwealth Funds Management is a relatively minor issue, but the possibility of privatising the management of the Commonwealth superannuation funds would be far more important because that directly affects all the contributors. It directly affects all the employees, of whom there are two or three hundred, but they are quite a small group in relation to Commonwealth Funds Management.

BREAK.PARA: I would be resolutely opposed to the privatisation of the management of the Commonwealth superannuation funds, and hope, therefore, that in the light of the kinds of principles I have articulated in this speech the government will not pursue that idea. But one hears rumours that it is being considered and therefore it is worth declaring a position on it quite early.
I do not feel strongly enough about this to oppose the bill. I do think that there is a case for not going ahead with it, but I am sure that is going to happen anyway.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with my colleagues the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) and the member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) in supporting the opposition's position, which is that we are not opposed to the CFM Sale Bill. They have set out the reasons fairly comprehensively. I will briefly comment in support of their position.

SPEECH.PARA: In general, my view is that this is an unnecessary bill. It is based on the wrong motives; it has not set out any objective criteria to justify the action. The closest we got to any objective criteria were actually those set out by the member for Werriwa, and amplified by the member for Fraser. They are a portent of worrying possibilities in the future, particularly those that the member for Fraser referred to in his concluding remarks.

As my colleagues have said, this is not a major matter and the opposition is not opposing the government's intention. It is not a major matter in terms of scale. We have here a minnow amongst Australian public sector agencies, and we have a matter that is not a quintessential or core public sector function.

Also, the issues are not controversial because the interests of contributors appear certain not to be affected by the change, and the interests of taxpayers are protected provided the price achieved is appropriate. I want to comment on whether that is going to be the case in terms of the timing of this matter in a moment. Nevertheless, in general, the interests of taxpayers are not adversely affected, apart from some comments I might want to make about timing.

There is an interesting precedent in terms of some of the matters that have led to the circumstances of this proposed sale, including some of them reflected in this legislation, of the extent to which the CPSU has been able to ensure that the interests of the affected employees of CFM are protected. This is an issue I think we will need to address more often if the program of privatisation and related contracting out in other matters persists, and it appears clear from this government's declared intention that it will. We will need to have a look at that question of the continuing rights and entitlements of employees who are working for the agency in question. There are some interesting precedents in what has happened here and it is an issue to look at in future.

I am concerned that the timing of this matter might lead us to a bit of a bargain basement sale. We are debating this bill on the day in which a significant adverse turn in profit performance for CFM appears in newspapers. There are a number of reasons that will explain that adverse turn and it is not something about which we should be alarmed, but it does indicate that we might not be proposing a sale at the time most likely to get the major return for the taxpayers. The profit results are low for a variety of reasons—one is to do with inherent volatility in return in this sort of industry. We are also proposing the sale at a time of major change in the activities of CFM. I do not have time to detail it and my colleagues have but, in essence, it is a product of the very proper and very important decision to break the monopoly of funds management of CFM which was made by the previous government and given effect to in the middle of last year.

That very important decision was the key decision to protect the interest of taxpayers and contributors and, at a time of that fundamental change and uncertainty—uncertainty about the success of CFM in this new competitive environment—it does appear to me that this is a very odd time to be making this sale, even if you were ideologically committed to the sale. I think it is a combination of ideological prejudice that drives a desire to sell every Commonwealth asset and a fixation with the budget bottom line this year that leads to bargain basement sales even where that may not be the most effective or successful way of protecting the interests of the taxpayers as the owners of this asset.

I do not want to dwell too long on the arguments about poor performance because I do not have time to do it, due to other commitments in the main chamber, but I think most of the focus on the poor performance of CFM is very short term. I have not been a member of parliament as long as some but during my period here in the parliament CFM, or at least its predecessor, the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust, was for at least one year the top performer amongst investment fund managers. I never felt that established that it was inherently superior to all the others, and the fact that in some subsequent years it has been otherwise does not make it inherently inferior. It is simply the different weight and balance of various funds. When property has a higher return than the stock market or cash, you find that companies like the then SFIT, Superannuation Fund Investment Trust, which had a weighting towards property, tend to be more successful. Its poor performances must be assessed in the circumstances that it only lost the exclusive mandate on 30 June last year and it is in the process of adapting to these changing circumstances.

But, while I lack any enthusiasm for the inherent intellectual rigour of the argument in support of this sale, you cannot get passionate in opposition to it because it is a very minor matter and is not a core public sector function. What is more, I recognise that, at the end of the day, if the sale does not go ahead, it is open to the government merely to let CFM run down without providing the resources to fund it effectively and operate it effectively, which leads to a hiatus in effective funds management, which is not in anybody's interest, neither the taxpayers nor the contributors.

The government has taken this initiative, as is its right as the party that won the election. The issues in it are not such that one feels disposed to go to the barricades against it. The consequences of not selling it in the circumstances of the budgetary options available to the government might be worse than selling it. So I join with my colleagues in saying—without enthusiasm, but in recognition of reality—that we will not be opposing this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fahey, John, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr FAHEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—In response to the debate in the Main Committee on the CFM Sale Bill 1996 I firstly thank honourable members, all of whom are supporting it. In view of the debate that has taken place, I think it is worth repeating that the government are simply moving to sell this asset because Commonwealth Funds Management are no longer the sole manager of the public sector funds—the CSS and the PSS.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the establishment of CFM in 1990, the legislative monopoly given to it in 1990, for a period of five years, has expired. As is their legitimate role, the trustees of the public sector superannuation scheme have gone to the marketplace in the interest of all members. And, in that competitive marketplace, there has been a running down of the assets being managed by CFM as the trustees have seen that they can obtain a service which is price competitive and which delivers the service to the members of those funds. So that is the first reason: the monopoly has gone and the business is diminishing as a result of the competitive market that is out there.

The second reason is that CFM itself is no longer managing solely the public sector funds. It has expanded its activities outside the public sector superannuation funds. It puts at risk their employment and they believe that being able to get some certainty back into the process is in the interests of themselves and their careers, and gives them the certainty that has been lacking.
