SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moylan, Judi, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mrs MOYLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

Despite a very high standard of living and generally adequate nutrition, significant illness and death still occur from diseases such as pertussis and measles, which can be prevented by immunisation. If enough children are immunised, outbreaks of these illnesses will be prevented. For example, in the United Kingdom, the recent measles‐rubella campaign has interrupted measles transmission in school children, and may have stopped the circulation of the virus throughout the population. In March and April 1995, only four cases of measles were confirmed: three had recently arrived from overseas. The fourth case involved an unvaccinated boy of 15 months. In Australia, with approximately one‐third of the population of the United Kingdom, there were 229 notifications of measles reported during the same period.

Low immunisation coverage rates continue to be of concern in Australia. Continuing epidemics of vaccine preventable diseases indicate that current immunisation rates are not sufficient to prevent the transmission of these diseases. There have been 300 cases of measles reported for the year to 17 August, 1996; 1,284 cases were reported during 1995; 4,895 cases, in 1994; and 4,536 cases, in 1993. Between 1983 and 1993 there were 41 deaths caused by measles. States and territories have been unable to adequately monitor immunisation coverage using consistent methodology, nor with a reasonable degree of precision. No state or territory is able to provide immunisation coverage estimates which can identify groups who are at risk of disease through incomplete immunisation.

In the 1994-95 budget, an additional $24 million was allocated to implement a number of initiatives to increase immunisation coverage rates and to curb the continuing outbreak of vaccine preventable disease. This allocation included funding to trial the Australian childhood immunisation register—called `the register'—for children up to six years of age, for a period of 18 months. The register is administered by the Health Insurance Commission, and it commenced operation on 1 January 1996. This government has guaranteed funding for the register beyond this 18‐month period.

It is anticipated that, for the first time, the register will provide a comprehensive, effective management tool for monitoring immunisation coverage and improving service delivery. Practitioners and immunisation providers have responded with enthusiasm to the new program and, already, a significant amount of information has been recorded on the register. Indications are that the register will grow to provide a comprehensive and valuable measure of immunisation coverage in Australia. Preliminary figures indicate that, up to 31st August 1996, approximately 1.6 million immunisation episodes have been recorded on the register.

The Health Insurance Amendment Bill 1996 will enable the Health Insurance Commission to release information from the register to prescribed bodies, for purposes relating to the immunisation or health of children. Commonwealth, state and territory health authorities and other prescribed bodies will be provided with de-identified information about immunisation coverage rates at national, state and local levels. This information will identify areas of high risk because of large numbers of unimmunised children and will therefore enable immunisation programs, including education programs, to be effectively targeted. With the consent of the parent or guardian, recognised immunisation providers will be able to establish the immunisation history of a child, before administering vaccines.

Parents or guardians will be able to obtain a statement by post of the immunisations administered to their child from 1 January 1996, regardless of where in Australia the child was immunised. This information will, over time, assist parents or guardians in providing evidence of their child's immunisation history for enrolment in child‐care facilities or school.

Information from the register forms the basis of an operational recall reminder scheme which will inform parents or guardians when their child's next vaccination is due or past due. Where a parent or guardian of a child opts out of the recall reminder scheme identifying information will not be released. However, the inclusion of these children in de‐identified reports will assist in the accurate determination of immunisation coverage rates.

Concern was initially expressed about the compulsory nature of enrolment on the register. However, immunisation is such an important health issue and the health of the community is best served by comprehensive information. An individual's choice to opt out of the recall reminder scheme will not compromise the safety of others in the community.

In addition, extensive consultation has taken place with the Privacy Commission. The bill prohibits the use of information by a person to whom it is divulged for the purpose other than that for which it was requested. Information from the register will not be linked with other Commonwealth databases. State and territory bodies will be required to give written confirmation to comply with the secrecy provision of the act before the information is released.

The implementation of the register will provide information which is not currently available about immunisation coverage. It will enable the Commonwealth, states and territories to better manage immunisation programs. The objective is to increase coverage rates to an extent that disease transmission is interrupted. Experience in other countries has demonstrated that this is an achievable goal. The establishment of the register is fundamental to achieving this objective. I table the explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I make my remarks, I thank the members present for their cooperation when we thought that another debate in the House of Representatives chamber was going to cause some need for me to be in two places at the one time. I appreciate the arrangements that people made in the interim.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition welcomes the government's introduction of the Health Insurance Amendment Bill on childhood immunisation. We welcome this decision because, in effect, it continues the previous government's initiative in childhood immunisation. The Labor government's original legislation established the national childhood immunisation register with the aim of improving our national performance by setting up a national system to remind parents about the timing of the necessary immunisations for their children.

The legislation also places appropriate privacy controls on the immunisation information and, very importantly, allows some parents to opt out of the system if they so choose, although the aggregate information will still be collected for public health purposes, which is commendable.

Although we strongly support the continuation of this national register, it is important to draw a contrast between this legislation and the government's policy in other areas. We have heard in recent months that, because of overlaps between federal and state responsibilities, the federal government intends accelerating the process of handing over powers and responsibilities to the states, not least aged care and some of the other responsibilities of the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan).

One of my concerns about the government's decision to accelerate the handover of these responsibilities to the states is the difficulties that have arisen in the last decade as the states took on additional responsibilities in childhood immunisation.

We found that when states had full responsibility for funding community health initiatives, state treasuries were quick to look at ways of making cutbacks and shutting down community health centres and baby health centres, which ultimately affected the nation's ability to ensure that as many of our Australian kids as possible were properly immunised.

The fact that both sides of politics are supporting this national childhood immunisation register demonstrates that when there is a real need in health, education or transport, it is often only the national government that has the resources to respond. Through the national childhood immunisation register both sides of politics are trying to address this need in our community.

BREAK.PARA: It is important to also remember that the former government not only funded the register but also agreed to meet the cost of some of the vaccines. That is also something which only the national government could have done and demonstrates once again that when important issues arise you often need the financial power and ability of the Commonwealth to deliver a service to every Australian wherever they may live—and that often makes the difference.

Clearly, the present government also agrees that it is critically important that the Commonwealth take over this vital area of public health and that is why we have the concerns that I have already mentioned. We do not want to see different standards and levels of care develop whether it is for aged care, education or lists of drugs available under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

Perhaps the worst recent example of the government's appalling record in trying to hand over responsibilities to the states has been the decision in this budget to abolish the Commonwealth dental health program with the ridiculous claim that state governments would pick up the slack.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has always been the states' responsibility.

—Certainly before 1993 that was the case. In dental health care, as in childhood immunisation, the states cannot do enough on their own. In 1993 a report showed that disadvantaged people were twice as likely to have teeth extracted rather than filled or repaired. There is probably no better argument in favour of the Commonwealth continuing to be involved in that area of public health than the fact that so many people were not getting access to what most of us would consider a basic right—that is, to have your tooth repaired and maintained rather than simply pulled out.

BREAK.PARA: Since the budget, state health ministers, Labor, Liberal and National, have made it clear that they certainly will not be topping up the funds, replacing the federal funds that have been withdrawn in dental health care. The same would happen if the federal government sought to hand over childhood immunisation responsibilities to the states.

I would like to make a couple of brief comments about some recent media stories about immunisation. The Quantum program on ABC television ran several stories warning the community about some of the risks associated with immunisation. An organisation such as the ABC with its proud record of many stories on public health issues also has a responsibility to be careful about some of the stories it broadcasts. It has to be careful not to needlessly alarm the public about the risks associated with immunisation.

I have some concerns about whether or not balance was achieved in that Quantum program. But I certainly commend the ABC for Dr Norman Swan's subsequent program on Radio National which presented a more balanced attitude to some of these issues.

I think that all of us accept that when people receive injections, or take medication, there is always a certain amount of risk that they could have a reaction to that medication, or the vaccine. But the chances of their health being affected in a negative way are more than outweighed by the benefits that young children, in particular, receive from immunisation. So we can only hope that all elements of the media try to take a responsible attitude in reporting these issues.

In conclusion, we in the opposition welcome the bill. In particular, we welcome its recognition of the crucial role of the Commonwealth government in making sure that national health priorities are met, and we urge the government to reconsider its intentions to give funding and control of a large number of other vital community health programs to the states that clearly have a demonstrably poor record on many of these issues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth, Trish, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the 1920s, the Commonwealth has undertaken to immunise against rubella, measles, the pertussis—otherwise known as whooping cough—meningitis, diphtheria and tetanus. This strategy is good preventive medicine and these immunisation programs have built upon, and are consistent with, the outstanding success of the World Health Organisation at eradicating smallpox.

SPEECH.PARA: This, in itself, is an argument for Australia's ongoing support of the World Health Organisation and associated efforts by the United Nations to rid the planet of these diseases. Anyone advocating Australia's withdrawal from the United Nations would best remember the unilateral efforts Australia is engaged in at the international level which benefit the health of people living right here in Australia.

Unfortunately, complacency can creep in, and I agree with the previous speaker, the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee), in calling upon the media to be responsible in the way they deal with these matters. On top of complacency, if there is any scaremongering about the side effects of immunisation, that can have a detrimental effect.

As the previous speaker said, with any medication there is always a very slight risk of a reaction which is undesirable. But for the overall public health of a community we must ensure that reliable information is out about the benefits of immunisation programs. In Australia, whooping cough and measles killed 457 children between 1980 and 1990 and in a survey conducted in 1992 it was revealed that up to 17 per cent of all children remain unvaccinated.

There have also been concerns that immunisation levels are lower for children from lower income families, Aboriginal communities and recent immigrants. When I was in Alice Springs, though, I was made aware that where programs of immunisation are well conducted by Aboriginal health workers themselves in their own communities the level of immunisation is actually at a higher level than in the wider Australian community. I think that those efforts must be recognised and those people commended for their efforts.

There was also the unfortunate fact that some parents and guardians remain unaware of the real threat to the health of their children, the need to complete an immunisation program once that has been commenced, and the need to remain vigilant in combating disease.

In the 1995‐96 budget, the Australian immunisation register was established to monitor immunisation coverage and to assist parents in the collation of information. The legislation was a response to a failure on the part of the states to adequately monitor immunisation coverage with consistency or methodology. Immunisation strategies are, by their very nature, a Commonwealth concern.

The ACIR commenced operations from the beginning of this year and nearly half a million immunisations were registered by April. The Health Insurance Amendment Bill 1996, now before the committee, deals specifically with the relationship between the ACIR and the Health Insurance Commission, and the current situation where the ACIR is prevented from sharing information with immunisation providers and the relevant state and territory immunisation bodies.

Importantly, this also restricts the ability of the HIC to remind parents that the next stage of their child's immunisation program is due. This bill will help ensure that Australia's national strategies and our contributions to international efforts to wipe out the diseases I have mentioned will be that much more effective.

With the desire to enhance the reporting ability and the distribution of information from the HIC, the Privacy Commissioner has expressed some concerns with the primary legislation to be enacted to address privacy and confidentiality issues. The Health Insurance Amendment Bill does enable the HIC to provide requested information to parents including important reminder notices. All children up to six years of age enrolled in Medicare will be included on the register and children not on Medicare records can be added by their local general practitioner. This bill ensures that no information about individuals, unless parental permission is given, will be divulged to relevant immunisation groups. However, cumulative information to implement regional strategies and identify outbreaks will now be available. This is an important measure which enjoys bipartisan support. We must be continually improving and updating our national immunisation program and, I hope, looking at what the latest medical research shows. I commend this bill to the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price, Roger, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an occasion when all parties in the parliament are working together for a very good cause and that is concern about preventable diseases and the protection of our young people.

SPEECH.PARA: We keep getting arguments about the need to rationalise responsibility between the various levels of government: federal, state and local government. In fact, immunisation has been traditionally an area that covered all three. Whilst I can understand why we would want to go for simple solutions, giving clear responsibility, it is not always possible. I think we are dealing here with an instance where that is the case. As much as some people—and I certainly do not share this view—might say, `Well, look, get the Commonwealth out of health completely and let the lines of responsibility and accountability be clear,' I come from the perspective that that is not always going to be possible. There is a legitimate role for the Commonwealth in health and sometimes when you devolve responsibilities it can be done with disastrous consequences. Our shadow minister, the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee), has already outlined that part of the regrettable result has been that immunisation rates in Australia have been dropping dramatically since this responsibility was devolved to the states.

It is a tragedy that in a country that we are all so proud of—Australia, with its relatively high standard of living—we can still be getting cases of reportable instances of illnesses in our young people that can be prevented by immunisation. I was very pleased that the shadow minister touched on the sensitive issue of concern by some parents and some groups within the community about the risks associated with vaccination. He is so right that in anything we do, even if it is just taking things like aspirin or penicillin, it is quite possible that people may have an allergic reaction but if we were to cease immunising—if we were to in fact recommend that people should not be immunised—what we would really be prescribing is more young Australians dying. I do not think any member in the parliament would stand up and feel comfortable with that.

The Health Insurance Amendment Bill sets out to provide a permanent status for the register of people who are being immunised and an automatic follow‐up system so that they can be reminded of the need to be immunised. At the same time people can opt out of that automatic reminder. That is their choice but I would certainly plead on their children's behalf that they do not do that.

I talked about the conflict between the different roles of the Commonwealth and states in the health sphere, and I want to give this second chamber an illustration of my frustrations and details of a very disturbing case that came to light today. I previously made representations on behalf of a young constituent, who is a pensioner in my electorate, about putting Daivonex cream back on the PBS system.

The minister did not actually write back but I got advice that the manufacturer was considering reapplying for the listing. If it had been listed then this problem may not have arisen, but the issue is that it was not. Unfortunately, my constituent was still in need of this prescription and went to a local chemist shop and was delighted when she was able to buy, for $25, this medication that would normally cost $50. If you are on social security benefits you can understand just what a tremendous saving this was.

The tragedy is that she bought it in September and its use‐by date was April and she has now had a severe reaction to it. She has gone to a doctor and to the specialist and is now awaiting the specialist's report, but her skin has been burnt and she is in some agony.

This is where the issue of accountability in health becomes a little difficult. Clearly, for example, chemists are regulated by pharmaceutical boards. I think it was completely unethical of the chemist in my electorate to sell out‐of‐date medication; absolutely unethical. I am surprised that there are not safety systems in place to prevent it, but I am sure that the state minister for health, after my representations, will be ensuring that this matter gets the proper ethical treatment.

Because it is not on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme it comes under the federal Therapeutic Goods Act. I say to the minister: what are the safeguards to ensure that this sort of incident does not recur? I find it distressing that it has happened once. The thought that a chemist in my electorate feels that, because we are just ordinary working‐class people, they can dump out‐of‐date medications on my constituents and they will not complain, I find horrific.

I am keen to learn from the minister—and the relevant minister is very sympathetic to this case—what the safeguards are to ensure that this is not a rort, that this is a one‐off case. I want to see a full measure of justice for my constituent. Unfortunately, I understand that we may not be able to restore her looks and relieve the pain she is going through, but if there is anything that should come out of this I want to ensure that this does not happen again. No chemist on the North Shore, no chemist in the eastern suburbs would dare do it, but because we are ordinary working class people they do.

I would like an assurance from the minister that the full measure of federal authority will be brought to ensure that this cannot happen again. If there is an organised rort, I hope the principals will be brought to justice. But here you have a case where, depending on whether a medication is on PBS or whether it is not on PBS, it circumscribes in some way the responsibility of the federal and the state governments. I am confident that Minister Wooldridge and Dr Refshauge will fully cooperate and investigate this quite horrific case. I sincerely hope that it is just limited to this one instance, but I have no confidence in that statement.

Returning to the bill, in immunisation we need cooperation between the state and federal governments. There is a legitimate role for the federal government in health, particularly immunisation. I say to all my constituents: please have regard for the welfare of your children and take the opportunity to ensure that your children are fully immunised.
I am pleased to again say that both the opposition and the government are cooperating on this measure and this bill certainly has my full support.

TALK.START.PARA: —Kaitlyn Gooding is six weeks of age. She lies in her cot in the childrens' hospital attached to an oxygen monitor by a network of tubes. Kaitlyn has whooping cough. Her coughing spasms can last up to three minutes as she struggles to get a breath. She coughs continually, going red in the face and, after a spasm, may vomit or even scream or cry.

BREAK.PARA: Her mother said it has been awful, she has been waking up distressed and has had spasms and then screamed—and she is normally a very placid baby. Kaitlyn has been coughing for about three weeks now. At first the doctors thought it was something minor, but one night she went blue and was rushed to hospital. The sad thing is that Kaitlyn and her parents had to unnecessarily experience this terrible ordeal, which could have been fatal, because other people had failed to immunise their children.

Whooping cough is a highly contagious disease that affects the air passages and causes difficulty in breathing. Severe coughing spasms occur and between these spasms the child gasps for breath causing the characteristic whoop. It is most serious in babies under 12 months of age, often requiring admission to hospital. Complications can include haemorrhaging, convulsions, pneumonia, coma, inflammation of the brain, permanent brain damage and long‐term lung damage. One in around every 200 children under six months of age who catch whooping cough will die.

The tragedy is that whooping cough is just one of eight diseases that can be prevented by routine childhood immunisation. Others are diphtheria, tetanus, polio, measles, mumps, rubella and Haemophilus influenzae type B, commonly known as HIB. Diphtheria causes a membrane to grow inside the throat that leads to difficulty in swallowing, breathlessness and suffocation. A powerful poison is produced and diphtheria bacteria may spread throughout the body. About 10 per cent of the people who contract diphtheria die.

Tetanus enters the body through a wound that may be as small as a pinhead and it attacks the nervous system causing severe muscle spasms, first felt in the neck and jaw muscles. The effects spread causing breathing difficulties, painful convulsions and abnormal heart rhythms.

Immunisation is the only effective way of giving children protection against these diseases. Immunisation has saved tens of thousands of Australian children from death and handicap and the benefit of protection against these diseases far outweighs the small risk of immunisation.

If enough people in the community are immunised the infection can no longer be spread from person to person and eventually the disease will die out. Since the introduction of routine childhood vaccination, smallpox has been eliminated from the world, polio removed from many countries and tetanus, diphtheria and measles are now uncommon. The threat of whooping cough has been reduced and we look forward to a virtual elimination of HIB, mumps and congenital rubella syndrome.

As more children are protected by immunisation, the prevalence of infectious diseases and people's attitude to these diseases has modified. Diseases are perceived as being less threatening and people start to feel that the immunisation is less important, and it is at this point that these diseases will re‐occur with a vengeance. In this context immunisation will be viewed as a victim of its own success.

Every parent wants their child to be protected from unnecessary illness, but they will only have their child immunised if they consider the risk from infectious disease serious and believe the vaccine is safe. For example, between 1983 and 1993 in Australia there were 41 preventable deaths caused by measles. Measles is a highly infectious disease and complications include encephalitis, pneumonia and ear infections which leave some children permanently damaged. I personally taught a child who had suffered ear infection and thereby was severely deaf as a result of a measles attack.

Between March and April 1995, there were 290 notifications of measles in Australia compared with only four in the United Kingdom. These are amazing statistics considering the United Kingdom's massive population when compared with Australia. I was shocked to read the Australian Bureau of Statistics study which shows that only 33 per cent of children aged three months to six years are fully immunised against mumps, polio, measles, whooping cough, diphtheria, tetanus, HIB and rubella. I was brought up with a mother who was a community and child welfare nurse who advocated that all children should be immunised and all children should be christened. I do not quite know why the two went together, but I always had that instilled in me, so I found these results absolutely amazing.

The survey highlights that while vaccination rates were up for measles, mumps and polio, the rates for diphtheria, tetanus and whooping cough fell sharply. This would explain why over 4,000 cases of whooping cough were reported in 1995. This government is determined to turn this situation around because there is no greater public health obligation that a country has to its children than to protect them from vaccine preventable illnesses.

I am pleased Dr Wooldridge committed himself, on the PM radio program, to provide leadership on this issue and to make sure that we raise the awareness that without immunisation we are exposing our children to very great risks. Immunisation will be a chief public health issue for the rest of the decade. With just 54 per cent of children immunised, we have the lowest level of child immunisation in the Western world. In fact, we rank 26 out of 28 in the Western world for complete childhood immunisation. Last year the rates for measles, german measles and whooping cough were 17 times the rate of five years ago. This means we are going to have more young boys becoming sterile from the complications of measles, babies being deformed from the complications of german measles and young children dying of whooping cough.

This year marks the bicentenary of the administration of the first smallpox vaccination developed by the father of immunisation, Edward Jenner. The development of immunisation during this century is one of the greatest medical successes, enabling health workers to prevent rather than treat disease. However, it is a national disgrace that, 200 years after Edward Jenner began his immunisation work, half of Australia's children have not been fully immunised. The government has made a major commitment to lifting childhood immunisation rates and, in the 1996‐97 budget, we have emphasised the importance of national childhood immunisation programs. To protect children from life‐threatening, preventable diseases, $2.5 million will be allocated in 1996‐97 in addition to the existing funding commitments. Consistent with the government's commitment to health throughout life, the program will be funded at $17 million in 1997‐98 and $15 million in 1998‐99.

Currently, no state or territory has been able to provide immunisation coverage estimates which can identify groups at risk of disease through incomplete immunisation. The government will make the national immunisation register an ongoing program item, with funding guaranteed beyond June 1997. And in consultation with the states and territories and with reference to the national register, the government will be able to set immunisation targets for mumps, measles and whooping cough. At the end of each financial year, the government will undertake an annual analysis of Australia‐wide performance and publish the outcome.

The government will use funding incentives to encourage state and territory governments to exceed their childhood immunisation targets. The government recognises there is still a concern in the community about the perceived risks of immunisation and also that some parents neglect booster immunisations for their children. The government will, therefore, fund a major ongoing publicity campaign through television, radio and popular magazines to advise parents about the importance of immunisation and the relative risks of not using a complete immunisation program.

It is anticipated that, for the first time, the national immunisation register will provide a comprehensive, effective management tool for monitoring immunisation coverage and for improving service delivery. Practitioners and immunisation providers have responded with enthusiasm to the new program, and already a significant amount of information has been recorded on the register. Indications are that the register will grow to provide a comprehensive and valuable measure of immunisation coverage in Australia.

The Health Insurance Amendment Bill 1996 will enable the Health Insurance Commission to release information from the register to prescribed bodies, for purposes relating to the immunisation or health of children. This information will identify areas of high risk and will enable immunisation programs, including education programs, to be effectively targeted.

Anti‐immunisation proponents propose that allowing a wild infection to occur in a healthy host engenders strong immunity. However, frequently, healthy unimmunised children will die from a vaccine preventable disease. Such advocacy is mischievous and, in view of the efficacy of immunisation, inexcusable. If none of the children in a child‐care centre of 150 were immunised and a whooping cough outbreak occurred, about 135 children would come down with the disease. On average, one child would get encephalitis. If every child in the centre were immunised correctly with four doses of DTP, the odds would be that possibly one child every 170 years could get encephalitis as a result of immunisation. Dr Aileen Aitken's article Australia's low immunisation rates: who is to blame? sums up this debate perfectly. She writes:

If somebody came into Australia and took 10,000‐12,000 children hostage and as a result some were so badly hurt they required hospitalisation and several of them died, it would be an absolute outrage.

Governments would act, the papers would be full of it, it would be on the news for weeks and the general population would be horrified. And yet, this is about the same number of children who have had vaccine‐preventable diseases each year for the last two or three years.

The facts for immunisation speak for themselves. Smallpox has been eradicated. Polio has been eliminated from many countries and, in Australia, the reduction in mortality cannot fail to impress. There has been a 91 per cent reduction in the incidence of measles since immunisation began in 1970; a 99 per cent reduction in tetanus and whooping cough; and a 100 per cent reduction in diphtheria and polio. Vaccination is the most cost‐effective means of disease prevention and control. All medical practitioners should ensure that their patients, both children and adults, are adequately immunised against all vaccine preventable diseases. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice there have been some important things referred to the Main Committee recently, but the Health Insurance Amendment Bill 1996 is probably one of the more important pieces of legislation that will be passed through this parliament. It is important in the sense that it will preserve the health and, indeed, the lives of many Australian children and those of many who are yet to be born.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian childhood immunisation register commenced operation under Health Insurance Commission regulations on 1 January this year, and this bill provides the establishment and maintenance of the register in primary legislation. It also provides the release of information from the register to specified bodies and persons. The establishment of the register is necessary to address continuing epidemics of vaccine preventable diseases.

BREAK.PARA: It is unfortunate that vaccination and immunisation have been hoist with their own petard in the sense that a younger generation of Australians thinks that in some way these diseases no longer exist when worldwide something like three million children die every year from the vaccine preventable diseases which this register will cover. The current levels of vaccination in Australia are such that only 53 per cent of Australian children are fully immunised.

The information contained on the register will provide parents or guardians with an optional recall or reminder system which will inform parents or guardians when their child's next immunisation is due or past due. We have reminders for vaccinations of pets—and I am sure the member for Cowan ( Mr Richard Evans) is aware of that from recent times—for the registration of cars, and for dental screenings; so why not have reminders for something as important as the immunisation of a child? In this sense, the previous government and, indeed, this government, are to be commended for taking the lead; although, as things develop, there will be people in the private sector who will clearly be involved in the recall and reminder system.

The register will also provide an effective management tool for monitoring immunisation coverage. Once identified, areas of low immunisation coverage can be further identified, enabling states and territories to specifically target education activities and resources. The register will be established by taking all records of immunisations received by the Health Insurance Commission after 1 January this year and transferring them to the register.

Parents who wish to are able to opt out of the recall and reminder system and, although I have some discomfort with that personally, I can understand the reasons for allowing that. Initially it will be operated by the Health Insurance Commission but, with the passage of time, it might be possible for it to be operated by immunisation providers recognised by the commission. But, before we can do that, we need to be satisfied that first and foremost the children are being immunised, that the register is working effectively and that the recall and reminder systems are going out before we devolve it too much into the private sector.

The Commonwealth will establish, and in fact has established, bilateral agreements with states and territories to cost share the data collection fee up to a maximum of $6 for immunisation. There is also a commitment to provide $3 reimbursement to recognised immunisation providers for the provision of data about NH&MRC—recommended immunisation episodes.

In this regard, whilst I would be the last person to argue that providers should be paid less for what they do, I think people ought to understand that whilst the $3 payment is appreciated, certainly by medical practitioners, in itself it is not the major driving force for immunising children. But it does recognise that there is time that a medical practitioner needs to spend complying with the necessary paperwork and administration of the register.

The estimated cost of the data collection component of the register is $2.43 million in 1995‐96, going to $4.93 million in 1996‐97. That is quite a modest expenditure when you consider what is at stake here. The funding allocated to the commission to establish and administer the register is just over $3 million in this financial year and $3.3 million for 1996‐97.

I would now like to make some general remarks about immunisation. Some members of the community may find it offensive, but I feel that it needs to be said. Immunisation is one of the most powerful and cost‐effective weapons against disease. With the exception of safe water, there is no other mechanism—in fact, not even antibiotics—which has had such a major effect on reducing death and improving population growth.

Other speakers have referred in passing to possible complications and accidents that may occur with immunisation. Like so many other important and significant public health measures, it represents a price that we pay for the protection that vaccines confer upon us. When you think about it, it is due to the large number of vaccine doses that are being administered at an early age when children are prone to various illnesses, and it is probable that there will be some temporal and time‐related and merely coincidental association between adverse events and vaccine administration.

I know from personal experience that, because you have children who are being vaccinated—certainly in the first year of life—roughly every eight weeks, if something adverse happens to the child it should not surprise us that parents and concerned relatives attribute whatever may happen to the child to the vaccine when, of course, in the first year of life especially, children are particularly susceptible to common diseases, some of them quite serious.

To put it into proper perspective, in the 1970s, for example, the fear of pertussis vaccine—whooping cough vaccine—reactions in the United Kingdom reduced immunisation rates from about 70 or 80 per cent down to less than 40 per cent. Subsequently, of course, there was an outbreak of pertussis.

Vaccines, as I said earlier, are victims of their own success. As diseases decline, adverse reactions gain in relative importance and the perception of risk as against benefit changes. One of the areas where Aboriginal people in particular are leading non‐Aboriginal Australia is in the area of immunisation, and I noticed the member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) referring to that earlier in her address.

For example, immunisation rates for children in the Top End of the Territory are in excess of 95 per cent. The reason for that, as I can tell you from my observations of aid development programs in Kenya and Tanzania, is that when people see children dying on a daily or a weekly basis from diseases, you have absolutely no trouble whatsoever convincing them of the benefits of immunisation.

If there were to be developed and launched today a safe and effective vaccine for AIDS, there would be a considerable queue lining up to receive it. In other words, people do not need to be convinced about the benefits of receiving it. Certainly, in the 1950s, when polio vaccine became available, most Australians did not need to be convinced that this was a good thing to go and get.

The media have a tremendous public health role to play by avoiding the transmission of sensational and, at times, biased and unfounded information about risks, when weighing them up against benefits. Recently, when I was on a plane, I saw an episode of Frontline which is a program that sends up current affairs television, and the producer of this fictitious program was very anxious to run a killer vaccine story because it would be very good for ratings. That, of course, is an extreme illustration of the irresponsibility of some people who permeate sections of the media.

Some of the best work that has been done on risk‐benefit ratios in relation to immunisation was done by a researcher called Holden, and published in 1987. He calculated the benefit‐harm ratio for common vaccinations. For example, the risk of dying from whooping cough, or suffering a serious complication of it, is 7,995 times higher than any risk at all conferred by the vaccine. The risk of getting tetanus and dying from it is 4,640 times higher than any risk conferred by the vaccine. Despite the fact we have not had a case of polio in Australia for over 10 years now, the risk of the problems from it are 990 times higher than any risk from the vaccine. The risks from measles, about which some parents, fuelled by some irresponsible sections of the community, including even the medical community, are 60,840 times higher than any risk at all conferred by immunisation.

He also calculated that in developed countries like our own—excluding the Aboriginal community—immunisation could prevent about 45 childhood deaths and 12 serious handicaps every month. In contrast, the program could cause one death every 22 years and one serious handicap every 7½ years. And that is in developed countries right throughout the world.

Some other points need to be made. For example, if you look at the 1981 outbreak of measles in New South Wales when the population was only 5.2 million, you will see that there were 2,200 hospital admissions, five deaths and a cost of $2 million in medical services. Middle ear infection, pneumonia, encephalitis are worth mentioning. For instance, you run a 1:2,000 risk of getting encephalitis if you contract measles and a 1:3,000 risk of death. Despite that sort of information, I remain surprised that some parents still need to be persuaded about the benefits of immunisation.

I referred earlier to the fact that only 53 per cent of children up to the age of six are being fully immunised, 30 per cent are only partly immunised, and 20 per cent are unimmunised, or their status is unknown. That, of course, is what this register and recall system is intended to address. Those figures are from the ABS national health survey.

This is a very good example of how we can achieve good things when both sides of politics work together. But those of us who are concerned for low income earners in Australia ought to be reminded that the poorest coverage for immunisation is amongst lower socioeconomic groups. Sixty‐five per cent of those earning less than $10,000 a year have their children immunised, whereas 85 per cent of those earning more than $70,000 a year have their children vaccinated.

Some of the problems that we have had include the fragmented funding arrangements between the public and the private sectors. Among the three levels of government there has been, at times, a lack of accountability. There has been poor data collection not only in relation to immunisation but also in relation to expenditure.

There has also been an enormous amount of effort put by governments of all political persuasions into cost shifting in relation to immunisation. Vaccine purchasing has, to say the least, been uncoordinated. Prices at times have been inflated due to the monopoly of supply. We have seen failures in the cold chain which the previous government and the National Health and Medical Research Council have worked very hard to address and we are hoping will be also addressed by the implementation of general practice accreditation. There has been fragmentation of delivery networks, poor record keeping, monitoring and recall, the last of which of course, this bill will actually address.

I would like to make some other points. If you look at a disease like measles, for example, you will see that we have had 136 cases this year to date, 1,284 cases last year, 4,895 cases in the previous year and 4,536 cases in 1993. There were 41 measles deaths in the decade from 1983 to 1993 and 57 Australian children died from whooping cough and measles in the decade from 1980 to 1990. Our vaccination rates in Australia, with the exception of Aboriginal people, as I said earlier, are poorer than countries like Tanzania, Iran, Colombia and Tunisia. That is not something of which we ought to be proud.

The other point that I would like to make is that those people in the community who promote homoeopathic vaccines should be reminded that they are just that; they confer no immunity whatsoever; there is no scientific evidence that so‐called natural therapies or homoeopathic vaccines provide any protection for a child at all. I never cease to be amazed when I hear parents saying that they do not want their child vaccinated because they might get a red lump or they might get a fever or that the neighbour's child was vaccinated and vomited for a day when what they are effectively doing is exposing their children, who are clearly precious and wanted, to something from which they could become seriously ill and in fact even die. You would not suggest to a parent that you would not restrain your child in a safety cot or that you would not put a seat belt on your child because you are frightened they might get bruised in an accident and yet that logic, which clearly says they are much safer in child‐care restraints in cars, does not apply in some cases to immunisation. I think doctors, in particular, who use their medical education to give legitimacy to some extremely dangerous views in relation to so‐called alternative vaccination, ought to be facing disciplinary action. I think it is no less of a disciplinary matter than a doctor who misses a case of pneumonia, than a doctor who misses meningococcal septicaemia, than a doctor who misses renal failure in a diabetic. To advise a parent that they should not have their child vaccinated against polio, measles, mumps, rubella, Haemophilus influenzae B or mengingitis and, instead, to take something which confers no scientific immunity at all as far as I am concerned is nothing less than medical negligence and throughout my public life I will pursue doctors who promote those sorts of views.

I realise that this is going beyond the bill but I have a reputation for being a troublemaker so I may as well continue in that vein! I cannot get my dog into a boarding kennel unless I have a vaccination certificate. I cannot get it in there for a week just to be looked after if I want a break because, if the dog has a disease—if it has not been vaccinated—it represents a risk to the others.

In a similar sense, if we have low levels of immunity in society for vaccine preventable diseases, we expose children who cannot be vaccinated for medical reasons—children whose immunity is suppressed, for example, through leukemia and cytotoxic drugs or children who are highly allergic to eggs, for example, and cannot be vaccinated against measles.

I ask myself: when are we going to live in a country where, prior to school entry, it will be necessary to present in every state and jurisdiction of Australia, evidence that the child has been vaccinated or, if the parent is a conscientious objector, that they have in fact been counselled by a medical practitioner—similarly for child‐care centres.

I realise in some parts of Australia that this kind of program has commenced but whilst we—and particularly on this side of the chamber—value individual freedoms, there comes a time when people exercising their so‐called freedoms seriously threaten the health and lives of others. It is time for us to say no. We think it is very much in the interests of everybody, including the children in question, that they be vaccinated and some very strong mechanisms should be put in place to see that effect is given to it.

So I will continue to advocate, at a personal level, that parents be required to show evidence of vaccination when a child goes into child care and/or at the time of school entry. If they are conscientious objectors—and I respect the fact that there are people like this around—then at least they have been counselled and a document has been signed to the effect that they understand the risks they are exposing their children to, but have nonetheless agreed to not have them vaccinated.

I commend this bill to the House. I also give credit to the previous government. I was a very strong critic of the member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence) when she was the health minister. I thought: what kind of health minister cannot get a $23 million immunisation package through the ERC and then the cabinet process in the 1994 budget? But she made a comeback on immunisation in 1994, and I give credit to her and to the previous government for that. We are now very determined to follow this through. Much of the reason this has been given such a high priority is the personal commitment of the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) not only to immunisation but to diabetes and other very important public health initiatives. I will be very keen to support this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forrest, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise with some enthusiasm to support the Health Insurance Amendment Bill 1996. I would like to take a different tack from other speakers and speak on a broader subject relating to something very dear to my heart—and my heart is my electorate. This legislation deals with one element of a suite of initiatives by the new government to address a very serious problem, that is, attracting doctors and medical practitioners to rural areas. And my electorate is no exception.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst the main initiative of the bill is to reduce the spiralling growth in Medicare payments, I can see that it will be of significant value in manipulating the position to some extent in attracting doctors to rural areas. When this is coupled with the additional announcements by the minister yesterday regarding overseas doctors, I will be watching anxiously for some benefits in the immediate short term. This is major reform and it is very difficult to explain, but I am committed to the concept.

Let me share some of the experiences I have had over the last three years as the federal member for Mallee, in north‐west Victoria. There are 24 hospitals in my electorate, spread right across it in the large communities, the provincial centres and very small communities. In a period of three years I have been involved actively in the placement of doctors for 12 of those 24. It is interesting that of the 12 doctors, who include some specialists, only two have been Australian doctors. It is quite a serious problem in my electorate and a serious problem right across the nation.

I note that the changes in the bill specifically relate to the requirement for medical graduates to complete postgraduate education in order to gain access to Medicare benefits. This is not about restricting employment options of doctors. It is limiting to some extent the unfettered access in a private practice to Medicare support underwritten by taxpayers. I can see that what this will do is require medical students to think about a different career option than necessarily practising in private practice. Many of my hospitals have complained that a young doctor is more interested in going into private practice, and the enticement of a Medicare provider number makes it just that much easier for him to do that. So the hospitals are left without vital medical support.

The bill results from a 1996 budget decision to restrict access to the Medicare system. Whilst it is often referred to as a decision to restrict the number of Medicare provider numbers, it is not that at all. I am having some difficulty explaining this to young graduates, a number of whom come from my electorate. But I hope they can see the broader vision. This is part of a major reform and, in conjunction with other major initiatives being announced by the government, will once and for all address this serious problem I have.

All of this is strongly linked to the supply of doctors in Australia. It has been reported that the Australian Institute of Health estimates that there is an oversupply of some 4,500 doctors right across the nation and a shortage of 500 general practitioners across rural areas. That is an ongoing frustration for those of us who represent that large proportion of Australia. To illustrate the comparison between metropolitan and rural areas, I can cite two examples. One is from New South Wales where there are 183 GPs per 100,000 people in Sydney, while the lowest number recorded is 68 doctors per 100,000 in the Murrumbidgee region—a significant rural area of that state.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I can interrupt the member for Mallee, the bill we are considering at the moment is a very specific one and your remarks seem as though they would be very appropriate to the Health Insurance Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996 which is not before the committee at this stage.

—Indeed they are, Mr Deputy Speaker. But I am trying to say that I regard this legislation as part of a suite of announcements by the government related to the very problem I am confronted with in my electorate.
—Perhaps the doctors you are seeking would be needed to carry out the immunisations which are related to the bill before us.
—Are you restricting me on this very necessary subject I wish to speak on? It does have relevance.

—I am prepared to offer some indulgence, of course, to the honourable member for Mallee. But I would remind you that there is an order of the day for the Health Insurance Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996 which would be the appropriate bill for you to make these comments on. Could you try to stay within the confines of the bill we are considering.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, all of my comments relate to the very immediate problem I have. I would point out to you that in Mildura, a provincial city with 22,000 people, they are currently seeking nine doctors and specialists. It is a very urgent problem for me. I believe that this piece of legislation relates to a whole suite of those coming before the parliament on a very specific policy by the government to address this very vital problem I have. All of the remarks I wish to make relate to that very vital question. So if you wish to rule me out of order, then I will cease and allow the parliament to get on with more urgent business.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say how grateful I am that these initiatives are receiving some bipartisan support. The previous government attempted as best it could, valiantly but unsuccessfully, to address the problem. We are now comprehensively addressing it. I just hope that in the next three years of my operations as a federal member, I will not have to have so much of my time involved in going right through the processes of medical registration and then those of the department of immigration, which can take 18 months. This can leave a hospital without medical support and puts its financial status at risk.

This very nearly occurred in the community of Manangatang. Two years ago, there was a deficit of $250,000. This Sunday, in conjunction with the current doctor who is there, I announced to the community that there was a new doctor. That is two doctors in a township of 300 people, but both doctors are foreign doctors, not Australian. That just highlights the point. But the fact is that the presence of the doctor has turned the hospital around financially and at the annual general meeting of the hospital a profit of $140,000 was announced. That is testimony to the necessity to have a good doctor and it is very sad that we have to rely on foreign doctors to achieve that. Mr Deputy Speaker, I will be making further remarks along those lines on the more relevant bill, as you suggest.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Mallee and I was pleased to provide some indulgence to him. But the chair would have been derelict in its duty if I had not made that point. I look forward to hearing your remarks on the appropriate bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this afternoon to address the Health Insurance Amendment Bill 1996. I can assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that my comments will be relevant to the bill at hand. This bill amends the Health Insurance Act 1973 to bring the Australian childhood immunisation register into primary legislation. The register was originally established by regulation but the Privacy Commissioner expressed concerns that, in the interests of protecting the information contained in the register, it should be brought into primary legislation. The bill also allows the release of information from the register to specified persons and bodies in specific circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: The register was established because vaccine preventable diseases are once again becoming prevalent in the Australian community and that causes me a great deal of difficulty. I have real problems with that. I recall that a few years ago Rotary International, in a program which was well supported and backed by all Rotary Clubs throughout Australia, went out into the worldwide community to collect millions of dollars to try to eradicate polio. It was not meant that any of the money would be spent in countries such as Australia—that is, developed Western societies—but that it would be spent on the less developed and the underdeveloped nations of our world to try to give children a greater chance at life.

I absolutely supported that program. It was an important program. It is unconscionable that we in Australia today face the fact that an ABS survey has found that only 53 per cent of children aged between birth and six years of age in 1989‐1990 were fully immunised, with another 29.5 per cent partially immunised. We have fallen way behind. The indication is that current rates of immunisation are so low that diseases such as measles, pertussis, which is whooping cough, and rubella are today more common than they were a decade ago. That is unconscionable. We should be taking care of our children and making sure that they are immunised against these preventable diseases. We have done the scientific research; we have done the hard yards. We have proved the case and here we are, lax in making sure that our own children are protected from diseases which may maim them, make them very ill or, indeed, take their lives.

In l995, 1,006 cases of measles, 48 cases of HIB, 97 cases of mumps, 2,757 cases of pertussis, 1,662 cases of rubella and three cases of tetanus were reported. There were no cases of diphtheria or polio reported. In fact, there have been no cases of polio reported since 1986. In the period from the 1940s to the 1970s, immunisation was a routine part of early childhood health care. As a result of those successful years of immunisation, many of the vaccine preventable diseases are virtually unknown to the new parents of today. These diseases can still occur and, because of their highly contagious nature, could very quickly spread to our schools and our kindergartens and, therefore, the general population.

The register will allow for parents to participate in a recall reminder scheme to inform them when their child's next immunisation is due or past due. This type of system has worked successfully for many years in some local government municipalities in Victoria. I recommend that model to much of Australia because it has been so successful. In that regard, I note that the City of Knox has had an outstanding program and other municipalities might do well to contact it to find out why its program has worked well and what they might do to emulate it.

The use of the Medicare database for establishment and updating of the register will mean that information is more current and more up to date, and the sending of reminder notices will be more regular and more easily obtained. The data available from the register will also enable areas with low immunisation to be more accurately targeted with immunisation specific education and resources.

Because we are looking at a national approach of prevention, perhaps the minister could consider in the future extending the register to cover students from seven to 16 years of age. Such an extension could catch many of those previously not immunised and could take in the teenagers who receive their adult diphtheria and tetanus shots in year 10 of high school. In the Australian Doctor magazine of 9 September 1994, Dr Mark Ferson reported that, of 166 cases of pertussis notified in eastern Sydney in 1993, seven per cent were in children aged less than five years, 28 per cent were in children aged five to 14 years and 74 per cent were in people aged 15 years and over. In 1994, pertussis vaccine was approved for use in children aged up to four years, but at the time Dr Ferson wrote that it was likely to be raised in the near future.

If we are genuinely serious about ensuring eradication of vaccine preventable diseases from Australia, we need to make sure that immunisation is kept up to date for all Australians. I wonder how many honourable members are currently immunised against diphtheria, tetanus and polio. Vaccinations do have a limited lifespan and a booster is recommended every 10 years for all of us. It is important that we take the lead in this debate on national immunisation and ensure that our own immunisation coverage is current. I recommend the bill to honourable members and to the Main Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moylan, Judi, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mrs MOYLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—With only 52 per cent of our nation's children fully immunised, this has presented as a major possible problem. It has been, I believe, a national disgrace that this has been allowed to go on for so long without being checked. The member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson) raised one important issue on the Health Insurance Amendment Bill 1996, and that was immunisation of children entering child‐care centres and schools. In that respect, New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory, and to some extent Victoria, although they do not have a compulsory immunisation program, have taken the NHMRC recommendations to introduce legislation requiring parents to provide evidence of immunisation status of children enrolling at child‐care facilities, preschools and schools. In the event of an outbreak of vaccine preventable diseases, unimmunised children can be readily identified and rapidly excluded from school or child‐care facilities for their own safety. I know that the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) supports that initiative and encourages the other states to follow suit.

SPEECH.PARA: I would just like to take a moment to thank all members in this Main Committee for their cooperation in this debate. It is a very important issue to the nation's children. Their health and wellbeing ought to be paramount. So I thank you very much for your cooperation and your contribution to this debate today. I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hardgrave, Gary, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 12 September 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the terms and conditions of the current lease arrangements for the Moorooka electorate office for the Member for Moreton.
(2) How do these terms and conditions compare to lease arrangements for other electorate offices.
(3) How does the cost per square metre compare to other electorate offices.
(4) Is he able to say why the former Member for Moreton chose this site.
(5) Did officers of his department recommend against this site; if so, (a) why and (b) is he able to say what justification the previous Minister gave for overriding departmental advice.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jull, David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Rental—$40,800 per annum;
Rent review—1 March each year; and
Term—6 years commencing 1 March 1995, with a determination clause which can be invoked three years after lease commencement.

(2) Leases for electorate offices are usually arranged for a 3 year term to coincide with the life of a Parliament. However, leases may be negotiated for a longer period on the basis that they include a determination clause which would enable the lease to be terminated after a given notice period.
(3) The cost per square metre is consistent with the average of electorate office rentals in Brisbane.
(5) This is a matter relating to the administration of a former Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Nairn, Gary, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 19 September 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: What are the Government's intentions for the future of (a) Casey House and (b) Scarborough House in Canberra.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jull, David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) The Government is currently seeking public expressions of interest for Casey House with the intention of leasing the building on a long‐term basis conditional on its heritage values being maintained. Casey House will be leased in its current condition and at a fair market rent that reflects that condition.

(b) Scarborough House is currently part of a construction project approved by Government in March 1995. This project comprises the construction of a new office building in Phillip (Discovery House) and the refurbishment of Scarborough House. Discovery House is under construction and due for completion in February 1997. At that time elements of the tenant of Scarborough House, Australian Industrial Property Organisation (AIPO), will move into Discovery House. Scarborough House will then undergo an extensive refurbishment which is due for completion by March 1998. The remainder of AIPO, currently located in Tuggeranong and several buildings in Phillip, will then move into Scarborough House.
